bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Librarian, Congressional Library, May 2, 1941

div1.p: Hench inquires as to whether the Library of Congress has a copy of Memoria del Hospital Numero Uno.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Office of the Librarian, Congressional Library, May 2, 1941
div1.opener:
May 2, 1941
Office of the Librarian
Congressional Library
Washington, D. C.
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
I am writing a monograph on the history of the
conquest of yellow fever, in particular the work of Walter Reed
and his associates. I have been trying to locate a history of
Military Hospital No. 1, the hospital in Havana, Cuba which was
occupied by the American Expeditionary Force about 1900. I have
just returned from Cuba where I learned that such a history
exists. It is entitled “Memoria del Hospital Numero Uno,
Correspondiente al ano de 1902. Presentada a la Junta de
Patronos por el Medico Director, Dr. Alfredo Valdes Galliol.
Habana---Imrrenta Mercantil. Teniente Rey Numero 12, 1902.
Republica de Cuba, Departmento de Beneficenera.”

May I ask whether you have this in your library
and if so, could you please write me to receive a letter while
I am at the Chalfonte-Haddon Hall, Atlantic City, from this
Sunday until Wednesday night. Enclosed please find an addressed
stamped envelope. If the book is available I will run down to
Washington to see it and perhaps I can borrow it through our
Mayo Clinic Library on inter-library loan.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
